Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Michael Ratz at the University of California, Irvine.

The proposed research aims at a better understanding of the fundamental constituents of matter. It also aims to unravel the nature of the mysterious dark matter that makes up 80% of the matter in the universe. The quest for the unification of all of the fundamental forces and particles has triggered some of the most important developments in physics. The aim of Professor Ratz's research is to make further progress on the quest for unification. The PI will approach these longstanding questions by using model-building techniques and by examining the experimental consequences of these innovative models at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and in underground experiments. As a result, research in this area advances the national interest by promoting the progress of fundamental science. The broader impacts of this research are to stimulate public interest in and appreciation for upcoming results in particle physics. These efforts are complemented by introducing undergraduate students to the frontiers of research in particle physics through, e.g., freshman seminars. Moreover, the PI will engage in public outreach in order to make this interesting field more accessible to the general public. Particular emphasis will be given to effective science education in undergraduate courses and promoting diversity in the graduate and undergraduate physics program. In addition, the PI will contribute to the COSMOS summer course for high-school students.

More technically, the PI will study symmetries beyond the Standard Model of particle physics. These comprise, apart from extra continuous gauged symmetries, discrete symmetries, which may involve an outer automorphism of the Standard Model gauge group. The PI will analyze the anomalies of such symmetries and explore their potential to solve the flavor and CP puzzles of the Standard Model. The PI will also study the extent to which such symmetries arise in potentially realistic string compactifications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research conducted in this project concerns symmetries for particle physics. The symmetries explored comprise traditional symmetries, outer automorphisms, i.e. operations that reshuffle symmetry transformations, and some rather new development, the so-called modular flavor symmetries. One result concerns the CP transformation, i.e the combination of charge conjugation, which inverts the charges of particles, and parity, i.e. a reflection of the spatial coordinates. This combined transformation could in principle be a symmetry of Nature, but it is not, which is instrumental for explaining the bayon asymmetry of the Universe, and so on. It is also linked to the violation of time reversal invariance. A new way to understand the origin of CP nonconservation was discovered: it could be linked to the flavor symmetries that arise in string compactifications. In order to fully establish it, not only the usual zero modes have to be considered, but also the so-called winding modes, which are specific to string theory, It then turns out that already the earliest stringy models of particle physics realize this mechanism of CP violation. Even though these models had been studied for more than 30 years, this has only been found now in the context of this project. Another point in which the literature was not entirely correct was the left-right parity of left-right symmetric models, and their generalizations. It turns out that this parity is automatically there in an SO(10) symmetry orbifolded by an order two transformation. More generally, even though the so-called orbifolds GUTs had been studied for two decades, the symmetry breaking pattern has only be understood now, in the context of this project. Further, this project also studied so-called modular flavor symmetries, a topic that gained momentum only very recently. The emerging models promise a very high predictivity while being realistic, i.e. consistent with observation. However, as found in the context of this project, the predictivity is not as large as claimed. This has opened completely new directions within this new development.
